STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 10, 2019
Alison Morrison
Shiawassee County DHHS
1720 E Main St
Owosso, MI 48867
RE: License #: CP780201406
Shiawassee County DHHS
1720 E Main St
Owosso, MI 48867
Dear Ms. Morrison:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on September
30-October 4, 2019. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Venus M. Decker, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(248) 639-9585
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP780201406
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768

Name of Facility: Shiawassee County DHHS
Facility Address: 1720 E Main St
Owosso, MI 48867
Facility Telephone #: (989) 725-3200
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1992

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in
R 400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(d) Known names, addresses, and dates of any previous
out-of-home placements.
Three child’s records were reviewed. One out of three records
did not have the previous placements documented in the child’s
record.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary.
Three child’s records were reviewed. One out of three records
did not have replacement preparation documented in the child’s
record.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
4

Three child’s records were reviewed. One out of three records
did not share information consistent with R 400.12417.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the
child, the child's parents or legal guardian, foster parents,
referring agency, and others, unless the agency documents
why any of these entities cannot be involved.
Three child’s records were reviewed. One out of three records
did not have a summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the child,
the child's parents or legal guardian, foster parents, referring
agency, and others, unless the agency documents why any of
these entities cannot be involved.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(d) Assessment of progress in achieving the
permanency goal for the child.
Three child’s records were reviewed. One out of three records
did not have an assessment of progress in achieving the
permanency goal for the child.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018 AND 2017
5

R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(e) A plan which includes any changes made since the
previous plan and which has the content specified in R
400.12419.
Three child’s records were reviewed. One out of three records
did not have a plan that included changes made since the
previous plan.
6

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy - FOM 723 - Page 5-6 - Transfer of Student Records to New School: If
the child’s case record does not contain the most recent school records, such as
the report card, discipline records, or IEP (if applicable), the caseworker must
request copies of educational records within five days of enrolling the child in the
new school. As soon as a school move is expected, or any time a child changes
school placement, a request for educational records must be sent to the former
school. The caseworker must request student records using the DHHS-942,
Education Records Release.
8

Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not have school records
or a DHS-942 in the file.
DHHS Policy - FOM 723 - Page 6 – Transfer of Student Records: with each change
of placement, including reunification, the case worker must transfer available
school records to the new placement within two weeks. This includes anything that
is available within the foster care case file
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not have documentation
that the new placement received school records. The child had three different placements
and education records were not in MiSACWIS for any of the replacements.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – Page 17-18 - Medicaid Card & DHS-3762 At the time of the
first placement: the care provider shall be given the Medicaid Number and a
Medical Treatment Authorization Card upon placement. If a child is not active on
MA at the time of placement, the caregiver must receive the MA card or
alternative verification of the child’s Medicaid status and recipient ID number
within 30 days of the date a child enters foster care. The date the foster care
worker provides the child’s Medicaid card or alternative verification and the
DHHS-3762, Consent to Routine, Non-Surgical Medical Care and Emergency
Medical/Surgical Treatment card must be documented in the placement detail
screen of MiSACWIS by checking the applicable box and entering date the cards
were provided.
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not have the DHS-
3762 noted as provided the placement.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – Page 17-18 - Medicaid Card & DHS-3762 At the time of
any replacement: the care provider shall be given the Medicaid Number and a
Medical Treatment Authorization Card at the time of the placement. The date the
cards were provided must be entered under the Foster Parent/Relative Caregiver
Input section of the case service plan. Additionally, for all subsequent
placements (replacements) the foster care worker completing the DHHS-69,
Foster Care Action Summary, must check the field box for the DHHS-3762 within
the information shared with new caregiver
Three child records were reviewed one out of three records did not have the DHS-3762
provided to them at replacement.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – page 11-13 Medical Passports - All medical information
required by policy and/or law must be provided to the foster parent. This
includes copies of the medical and dental examinations (if available) and the
information required in the medical passport. For children first entering foster
care, the initial medical passport must be provided to the caregivers within
two weeks of the child's placement date. The actual date the caregivers
receive the medical passport must be documented in MiSACWIS. All medical
information within the medical passport must be current and updated at least
9

quarterly to reflect the child's current and complete health information.
Placement agency foster care (PAFC) providers must provide a copy of the
medical passport to MDHHS monitoring staff as it is updated but no less often
than annually. Each foster care worker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another foster care worker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the necessary
information under law and MDHHS policy. An updated medical passport is
provided to: Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
ll medical and mental health professionals to whom the child is referred and
accepted for treatment.
o The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each placement. This
includes foster homes, relative placements and residential facilities.
o Legal parents quarterly and at reunification, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child is referred
and accepted for treatment
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not have medical
passports completed quarterly.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018
DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 3-4 – Parenting time Supervision: Did the caseworker
personally observe parenting time at least once a month
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not have
documentation that parenting time was personally observed by the caseworker.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018
DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 4-5 –Parenting time age of child: The frequency of
parenting time is based on the age of the youngest sibling.
Newborn to age five, visits occur, at a minimum, two times per week.
Ages six and older, visits occur, at a minimum, once a week.
Three records were reviewed. Two out of three records did not have parenting time
occur as noted as above. One record did not have parenting time from 2/8/19-2/20/19
and 3/8/19-3/20/19. There were no exceptions noted in MiSACWIS. Twice a week
parenting time was to be completed. The second record did not have parenting time
documented from 10/3/19-1/28/19. Parenting time did not occur in 2/2019. There was
one exception noted in MiSACWIS from 1/1/19-1/29/19.
DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 4-5 –Parenting time barriers documented: If visits did
not meet the above minimum requirement the barriers that are contributing to
less frequent visits and how those barriers are being addressed must be
documented in the case service plan.
10

Three children records were reviewed. Two out of three records did not have
documentation discussing parenting time barriers.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06I – Page 10 - Parenting time Incarcerated parent: Have
efforts been made to arrange visitation with an incarcerated parent
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not document what
efforts have been made to arrange visitation with an incarcerated parent.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - Page 5 - CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN OUT-
OF-HOME PLACEMENT: The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts per month with the child for the first two months following an initial
placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face contact with the child must
take place within five business days from the date the case is assigned to the
caseworker or within five business days of the date of the placement move.
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three did not have a face to face contact
completed within the first five days of the initial placement..
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H – Page 7 -– Unannounced Home Visit - The
caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home every quarter. The
unan¬nounced visit must be documented in MiSACWIS.
Three child records were reviewed. Two out of three did not have quarterly
unannounced visits documented.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018 AND 2017
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H - Page 10 – CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH
PARENT(S)/ GUARDIAN(S): during the first month of out of home placement, the
caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts with each
parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in the parent’s residence.
During subsequent months, the caseworker must have face-to-face contact with
each parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least one contact
in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of residence.[Citation Box
includes required conversation topics during first month]
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not have two face to
face contacts with the parents, one in the residence within the first month.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018 AND 2017
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H Page 1-3 – OVERVIEW and QUALITY VISIT
STANDARDS
11

Assess safety, wellbeing, child’s needs, ongoing services, permanency plan, goal
progress, effectiveness of services.
Quality visit: Individual meetings, safe sleep,
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H - Page 3 - The following topics must be discussed
with the child at each visit and documented in the service plan:
- Child’s feelings/observations about the placement.
- Education.
- Parenting time.
- Sibling/relative visitation plans.
- Extracurricular/cultural activities/hobbies since last visit.
- Permanency plan.
- Medical, dental, and mental health.
Any issues or concerns expressed by the child.
Three child records were reviewed. One out of three records did not have quality visit
standard documented.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H p 15 TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS within five business days
of the contact.
Three child records were reviewed. Two out of three records did not have case notes
completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION-RENEWAL 2018 AND 2017
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas: CHRI in
borrowed bed files.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas: Documentation of case
notes with parents who are homeless.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
12

The corrective action plan was completed.
VII. Analyst Contacts
There are no safety concerns or alerts initiated.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
October 10, 2019
________________________________________
Venus M. Decker Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
________________________________________
Date
Area Manager
13
